title: 114_s1109
content: The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" requires federal agencies to provide information on settlement agreements. The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" mandates that federal agencies disclose details of settlement agreements meeting specific criteria, including those involving alleged violations of federal law requiring payments of at least $1,000,000 by non-federal entities. The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" requires Executive agencies to disclose settlement agreements involving alleged violations of federal law that require payments of at least $200,000 in attorney fees, costs, or expenses to non-Federal entities. The term 'entity within the Federal Government' includes officers or employees acting in an official capacity, while 'non-Federal person' refers to individuals outside the Federal Government. Additionally, the Act defines 'rule making' as per section 551(5) and mandates that Executive agencies make this information publicly available online in a searchable format. The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" requires Executive agencies to disclose covered settlement agreements online, including the date, names of parties, description of claims, and settlement amounts. The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" mandates Executive agencies to disclose covered settlement agreements online, detailing the claims settled, amounts each party is obligated to pay, total settlement amount, and any civil or criminal penalties specified for each party. The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" requires Executive agencies to disclose covered settlement agreements online, including details on penalties, non-deductible amounts, deposit locations for collected funds, and copies of each settlement. The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" mandates Executive agencies to publicly disclose covered settlement agreements, including penalty details, non-deductible amounts, and deposit locations for collected funds, for a minimum of 5 years. Disclosure is required unless confidentiality provisions prohibit it. The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" requires covered settlement agreements to be publicly available for a specified period, with exceptions for confidentiality provisions deemed necessary to protect the public interest by the head of an Executive agency. The head of an Executive agency can issue a public statement explaining the need for confidentiality in a covered settlement agreement to protect the public interest of the United States. The statement must detail why confidentiality is necessary, what interests it protects, and why these interests outweigh the public's right to know about government conduct and spending. Additionally, any public statement mentioning payments by a non-Federal party in a settlement agreement must specify if any portion is designated as a civil or criminal penalty. The covered settlement agreement by a non-Federal person must specify if any portion is a civil or criminal penalty or fine for violating Federal law. If no such portion is specified, a statement to that effect must be included. Details of actions or payments in lieu of monetary compensation to the government must also be described. The covered settlement agreement by a non-Federal person must specify civil or criminal penalties for violating Federal law. Details of actions or payments in lieu of monetary compensation to the government must be disclosed, subject to confidentiality provisions. Executive agencies must report on covered settlement agreements annually to Congress. The Executive agency must report annually to Congress on covered settlement agreements, including the number of agreements, confidentiality terms, total attorney fees paid, and the number of agreements with non-Federal persons. The Executive agency must report annually to Congress on covered settlement agreements, including the number of agreements, confidentiality terms, total attorney fees paid, and the number of agreements with non-Federal persons. The agency is required to make the report publicly available on its website in a searchable format. Additionally, a technical and conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 3 of title 5, United States Code. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress on how Executive agencies determine the confidentiality of settlement agreements within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The report will include recommendations for increasing transparency while protecting legitimate interests. The Senate passed this on September 21, 2015.
